problem: If $4u-5v=23$ and $2u+4v=-8$, find the value of $u+v$.
solution:
We can begin by multiplying the second equation by two, giving us the following system of equations \begin{align*} 4u-5v&=23
\\ 4u+8v&=-16
\end{align*}From here we simply subtract the second equation from the first. This gives us $(4u-5v)-(4u+8v)=23-(-16)$, which simplifies to $-13v=39$ or $v=-3$. We now know the value of $v$, so we can just plug this into the first equation in order to solve for $u$. This gives us $4u-5(-3)=23$, or $4u=8$ and $u=2$. Since $v=-3$ and $u=2$, $u+v=2+(-3)=\boxed{-1}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: Multiply the two equations by necessary multiples such that the coefficients of $v$'s in both equations are the same.
$\begin{cases}
4u-5v=23 \\
2u+4v=-8
\end{cases}$
Step 2: 
$\begin{cases}
4u-5v=23 \\
5(2u+4v)=-5(-8)
\end{cases}$
$\begin{cases}
4u-5v=23 \\
10u+20v=-40
\end{cases}$
Step 3: 
$\begin{cases}
4u-5v=23 \\
10u+20v=-40
\end{cases}$
$\begin{cases}
4u-5v=23 \\
10u+20v=-40
\end{cases}$ 
$\begin{cases}
-5v-20v=-40-23 \\
4u+10u=23-(-40)
\end{cases}$
$\begin{cases}
-25v=-63 \\
14u=63
\end{cases}$
$\begin{cases}
-25v=-63 \\
14u=63
\end{cases}$
$\begin{cases}
v=\frac{-63}{-25} \\
u=\frac{63}{14}
\end{cases}$
$\begin{cases}
v=\frac{63}{25} \\
u=\frac{63}{14}
\end{cases}$
$\begin{cases}
u=\frac{63}{14} \\
v=\frac{63}{25}
\end{cases}$
$u+v=\frac{63}{14}+\frac{63}{25}$
$u+v=\frac{63}{14}+\frac{63}{25}=\frac{63\cdot5}{14\cdot5}+\frac{63\cdot2}{25\cdot2}=\frac{315}{70}+\frac{126}{50}$
$\frac{315}{70}+\frac{126}{50}=\frac{315\cdot5}{70\cdot5}+\frac{126\cdot7}{50\cdot7}=\frac{1575}{350}+\frac{882}{350}$
$\frac{1575}{350}+\frac{882}{350}=\frac{1575+882}{350}$
$\frac{1575+882}{350}=\frac{2457}{350}=\frac{819}{116.6667}$
$\frac{2457}{350}=\frac{819}{116.6667}$
